_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Basic Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Millennium Inorganic Chemicals, Inc. safety, health and environmental policy provides the foundation for risk management programs at the Hawkins Point Plant ("HPP").  In keeping with policy, the facility has developed a comprehensive safety management program that strives to identify and eliminate potential exposures.  The program strives to control potential exposures that include, but are not limited to, personal injury/illness, property damage, fires, process incidents and security incidents.  The HPP safety program includes the following commitment statement.

"There is no activity or job at the Hawkins Point Plant which is so important or urgent that it must be done at the jeopardy of the safety or health of any employee or contractor, or at the risk of damaging the environment.

Any employee or contractor at the Hawkins Point Plant has the authority and obligation to stop any activity or job which they feel may jeopardize the safety or health of any employee or contractor, or which may risk damaging the environment."

Management at HPP has authorized specific risk management programs and activities in compliance with EPA's "Risk Management Program" (40 CFR 68) that:

Assess the hazards of processes which handle or store more than the threshold quantity of substances regulated by EPA,
prevent accidental releases of these hazardous substances, and 
effectively respond to emergencies if a release occurs.

HPP produces titanium dioxide by the chloride process for shipment to external customers.  The covered process is the titanium dioxide manufacturing plant.  This process uses two chemicals included on the EPA regulated list, namely chlorine and titanium tetrachloride.

During the five years prior to the date of this report, there were no releases of chlorine or titanium tetrachloride that caused an offsite impact or employee/contractor injuries.

HPP has a comprehensive emergency response plan that is tailored to the process and covered a variety of differen
t types of potential emergencies.   This plan is coordinated with off-site emergency response agencies and other local facilities.
